Project Description

The Project will improve the well-being of people affected by the 18-
year long conflict in the Northern and Eastern provinces of Sri Lanka
through  providing  housing  and  basic  services  for  those  who  have
been  displaced  by  the  conflict,  improving  health  and  education
facilities, reestablishing agricultural and fishing activities as a means
of  providing  incomes  to  people  who  are  presently  dependent  on
welfare  payments,  and  mobilizing  communities  to  become  involved
in implementing Project-financed activities.

Rationale

The  armed  conflict  between  the  Sri  Lankan  government  and  the
Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam commenced in 1983. About 60,000
people have been killed, and a further 700,000–800,000 have been
displaced, a substantial proportion repeatedly. The conflict has also
destroyed  or  damaged  houses,  infrastructure,  and  livelihoods,  and
has  led  to  redistribution  of  ethnic  populations,  loss  of  access  to
markets  and  social  services,  and  minimal  functioning  of  the  civil
administration  in  the  Project  area.  The  disruption  of  economic
activity  is  estimated  to  have  decreased  the  contribution  of  the
Northern  and  Eastern  provinces  to  national  gross  domestic  product
from 15 percent in the 1980s to 4 percent in 1997. The scale of the
destruction and dislocation has so strained the Government’s ability
to  provide  assistance  that  it  has  turned  to  the  international
community for support. The Government has in particular requested
the  Asian  Development  Bank,  as  one  of  its  leading  development
partners, for assistance.

II.

INTRODUCTION

Since  1983,  Sri  Lanka’s  Northern  and  Eastern  provinces  have  been  a  battleground
2.
between the Government’s armed forces and the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE),
who  are  seeking  by  force  the  creation  of  a  separate  state  that  would  encompass  both
provinces. The conflict has varied in intensity from time to time, and from area to area, but
has resulted in at least 60,000 deaths, and in the displacement of 700,000–800,000 people,
many of whom now live in refugee camps, referred to officially as welfare centers.

3.
The  Government  has  established  a  number  of  agencies  and  programs  to  provide
assistance to these displaced people in the form of basic shelter, food rations, and welfare
payments. However, the Government sees the need to move as many of these people away
from the dependency of life as refugees and back into a more independent a way of life as is
possible  under  the  present  circumstances,  either  in  their  original  locations  or  in  relocation
areas.  The  proposed  Project,  which  was  prepared  through  an  Asian  Development  Bank
(ADB)-financed  small-scale  technical  assistance  (TA)1  will  assist  the  Government  with
implementing  this  program  of  community  restoration  throughout  the  Project  area,  which  is
broadly defined as the entire Northern and Eastern provinces (see map).

4.
The Project has been processed at the request of the Government and in accordance
with ADB’s procedures for rehabilitation assistance after disasters.2 Although the conflict that
has  led  to  the  need  for  assistance  continues  the  people  whom  the  Project  will  assist  have
largely  been  forced  from  the  areas  of  most  intense  confrontation.  Now  confined  to  poorly
served welfare centers, and deprived of most of the basic requirements for a productive and
meaningful  existence,  they  are  effectively  in  the  same  situation  as  people  elsewhere  who
have  been  displaced  by  a  disaster,  and  who  now  require  assistance  to  resume  their  lives.
Unlike  other  post-disaster  situations,  most  of  the  affected  people  will  not  return,  at  least  in
the near future, to their original places of residence. Their lives will be rebuilt elsewhere. The
Project will assist them to do this.

While the conflict continues there is the risk that assets created by the Project could
5.
be  destroyed  should  the  conflict  widen  or  intensify.  Project  risks  are  discussed  in  detail  in
paras.  89–91.  In  brief,  the  Project  will  make  arrangements  with  the  Government  and  other
parties involved in prosecuting, and addressing the impacts of, the conflict to ensure to the
extent  possible  that  Project-created  assets  will  be  preserved.  In  addition,  the  Project  will
finance  major  investments  only  in  areas  that  are  reasonably  free  of  conflict;  investments  in
areas  still  subject  to  conflict,  including  those  not  under  the  Government’s  control,  will  be
smaller  scale.  The  potential  cost  of  losing  some  of  these  investments  early  in  their  useful
lives will be more than offset by the benefits gained by a significant proportion of the people
displaced  by  the  conflict,  many  of  whom  are  now  existing  in  the  welfare  centers.  These
benefits  will  include  relocation  to  new  homes,    improved  availability  of  medical  care,
education,  basic  services  such  as  water  supply  and  drainage,  and  access  to  income-

BACKGROUND4

The  armed  conflict  between  the  Sri  Lankan  government  and  the  LTTE,  who  are
7.
fighting  for  a  separate  state  in  the  northeast  of  the  country,  commenced  in  1983,  although
the causes of the conflict go back much further. Deaths due to the conflict are estimated to
be  around  60,000,  while  the  estimate  of  the  displaced  population  is  700,000–800,000  or
approximately 5 percent of the country's entire population. Almost two thirds of households in
the north and east have been displaced, a substantial proportion repeatedly. The estimated
displaced  population  varies  among  the  eight  districts5  making  up  the  Northern  and  Eastern
provinces,  but  appears  to  be  highest  in  Mannar,  at  95  percent.  The  eight  districts  have
become separated into so-called cleared and uncleared areas. Cleared areas are under the
control of the Sri Lankan Armed Forces, while uncleared areas are under LTTE control. The
reality on the ground is, however, more complex: In the north, cleared and uncleared areas
are  generally  demarcated  by  a  front  line  with  fortified  structures  on  both  sides.  In  the  east,
the  situation  is  more  fluid;  many  areas  are  semicleared,  subject  to  ongoing  instability  and
sporadic  conflict.  Outside  main  towns,  LTTE  presence  tends  to  be  strong.  Notwithstanding
this  demarcation,  the  Government  continues  to  provide  services  in  the  uncleared  areas,
albeit with considerable difficulty and to a much lower level than in the cleared areas. These
services  include  education,  health,  relief  food  supplies,  power,  and  banking,  among  many
others.

2.

Social Impacts

11.
The  conflict  has  resulted  in  the  loss  of  lives,  houses,  and  lands;  destruction  of
economic  and  social  infrastructure  and  livelihoods;  maiming  and  displacement  of  people;
redistribution  of  ethnic  populations;  disruption  of  ethnic  trading  networks  and  patterns;
restrictions  on  the  mobility  of  people  and  goods  due  to  security  checkpoints  and  a  strictly
enforced  pass  system;  lack  of  access  to  markets  and  social  services;  and  the  minimal
functioning of civil institutions and  administration.

12.
Households  displaced  due  to  conflict  have  sought  shelter  in  overcrowded  welfare
centers  (Appendix  2  provides  an  insight  into  the  experiences  of  people  in  these  centers).
Food  is  scarce  both  in  and  out  of  the  centers,  with  resulting  malnutrition.  Bans  have  been
imposed  on  transporting  construction  materials,  agricultural  inputs,  fuel,  food,  and  other
household items to uncleared areas, leading to hardship and deprivation for the people who
remain there. The conflict has also increased the numbers of female-headed households and
orphans  throughout  the  country.  The  gender  implications  are  that,  while  women  are
burdened with more responsibilities, they have also gained greater authority and autonomy
within  their  families  and  communities  as  they  are  increasingly  forced  to  take  on  the  role  of
household head and principal income earner.

13. While the war has created refugees and IDPs who are particularly vulnerable to lack
of  basic  needs,  other  people  in  the  conflict-affected  zones  are  similarly  affected.  Already

3.

Economic Impacts

The  conflict  severely  affects  the  country’s  macroeconomic  stability.  High  defense
14.
expenditures  and  the  large-scale  rehabilitation  program  hinder  the  Government’s  ability  to
reduce  the  fiscal  deficit.  Defense  expenditures  have  increased  from  1.3  percent  of  gross
domestic  product  (GDP)  in  1980  to  4-6  percent  of  GDP  in  recent  years.  In  2000,  the
Government  spent  nearly  $1  billion  on  defense,  more  than  the  amount  spent  on  education
and health combined. The high deficits raise interest rates, crowding out private borrowing,
and cause the balance of payments to deteriorate, depleting the official foreign reserves. The
drain in reserves culminated in the floating of the currency in January 2001 and the recently
concluded agreement with the International Monetary Fund to provide balance of payments
support.

15.
The  quantifiable  costs  from  the  war,  in  terms  of  direct  losses  from  the  fighting  and
indirect costs on the rate of growth, were greater than total GDP in 1995.7 In its 1999 Annual
Report, the Central Bank of Sri Lanka estimated that the conflict has reduced the country’s
economic growth rate by about 2-3 percentage points a year. The conflict has damaged Sri
Lanka’s reputation in the eyes of foreign and domestic investors, who are reluctant to make
new major investment commitments.

16. What  is  less  apparent,  but  equally  important,  is  the  fact  that  the  conflict  precludes
growth  in  sectors  that  hold  high  potential  for  creating  productive  employment  for  the  poor.
Sri Lanka has a natural advantage in tourism. The establishment of a large stock of hotels,
visitor  sites,  and  a  modern  airport  in  the  1970s  and  early  1980s  was  designed  to  tap  this
robust global market.  As a result of the conflict, visitor arrivals have been stagnant, and Sri
Lanka has been unable to penetrate the higher value tourist market. Security considerations
have  also  limited  Sri  Lanka’s  ability  to  develop  as  a  regional  service  hub.  The  conflict  has
prompted the out-migration of large numbers of skilled and semiskilled workers, depriving the
economy of trained professionals, entrepreneurs, and highly skilled civil servants the nation
needs.

4.

Impacts on Government Operations and the Government’s Response

17.
Government services continue to operate in the Project area, including in uncleared

1.

Impacts on Health

21.
The  continuing  conflict  has  had  a  major  adverse  impact  on  the  health  status  of  the
population in the North East. For example, in 1980 Jaffna had the best health status in the
country, and overall the health status in the Project area was comparable with the rest of the
country. Current data indicate that there has been a 25–50 percent decline in all major health
indicators.  There  are  sharp  increases  in  the  incidence  of  malaria,  typhoid,  dysentery,
infectious  hepatitis,  and  respiratory  ailments;  in  diseases  resulting  from  inadequate  and
contaminated water supplies and from lack of effective sanitation; and in disabilities resulting
from conflict-caused injuries. The infant mortality rate in the Project area increased from 11
per 1,000 live births in 1985, which was lower than the then national average, to 30 in 2000,
whereas  the  national  average  declined  to  16.  This  situation  is  due  largely  to  severe
shortages of health service personnel and drugs, particularly in the welfare centers and the
uncleared  areas,  poor  preventive  health  care,  inadequate  nutrition,  and  lack  of  access  to
clean water and sanitation. The  conflict has also resulted in significant increases in physical
injury; disablement; and the incidence of septicemia, gangrene, and tetanus and has created
an urgent need for rehabilitation for physical disablement and for the psycho-social impacts
of the conflict on individuals and communities.

22.
Health  resources  in  the  North  East  are  currently  greatly  overstretched,  and  service
delivery  in  the  uncleared  areas  is  extremely  limited,  with  tight  restrictions  imposed  by  the
security forces on the distribution of drugs and surgical equipment. The shortage of medical
and  paramedical  personnel  is  a  major  concern,  with  high  vacancy  rates  reported  in  all
positions  including  doctors  (32  percent  of  positions  unfilled,  despite  doctors  being  paid  a
substantial hardship allowance for working in the North East), specialists (80 percent), dental
surgeons (34 percent), midwives (54 percent) and nurses (47 percent).

23.
Malnutrition  and  undernutrition,  particularly  among  young  children  and  pregnant
mothers,  are  widespread.  A  recent  survey  in  Trincomalee  found  that  an  average  of  51
percent  of  children  under  five  years  old  were  underweight,  compared  with  the  national
average  of  13  percent.  Stunting  of  growth,  indicating  long-term  undernutrition  and
malnutrition, is also common, particularly in the uncleared areas (up to 42 percent, compared
with the 22 percent national average). Over one quarter (26 percent) of young children were
found  to  suffer  from  wasting,  twice  as  high  as  the  national  average  (13  percent).  Tamil
children  in  the  North  East  are  particularly  vulnerable  to  both  wasting  and  stunting  (53.5
percent and 34.4 percent respectively), in contrast to Singhalese children (41.5 percent and
15 percent) and Muslim children (33.9 percent and 16.4 percent).

24.
Physical  infrastructure  is  also  in  need  of  major  rehabilitation,  either  because  the
conflict  has  damaged  or  destroyed  hospitals,  clinics,  etc.,  or  because  populations  have
moved  away  from  conflict  areas  and  are  now  imposing  demands  on  health  infrastructure
beyond  what  it  was  designed  to  carry.  This  applies  particularly  in  Vavunia,  where  much  of
the  northern  population  has  relocated,  and  to  a  lesser  extent  in  Batticaloa,  Mannar,  and
Trincomalee.  The  needs  are  many,  and  include  additional  facilities  and  accommodation  for
patients and staff, replacement and additional equipment, mobile clinics, and hospital waste
disposal and sanitation systems.

25.

2.

Impacts on Education

27.
The education system has been severely disrupted, with destruction and damage to
school  infrastructure  and  facilities,  and  occupation  of  schools  by  security  personnel.  Of  the
1,900  schools  in  the  Project  area,  about  180  are  temporarily  closed.  Many  of  the  others,
particularly in the larger towns to which populations from the north have relocated, are now
operating at well beyond their capacity. Displacement has resulted in thousands of children
missing  years  of  schooling.  Staff  shortages  are  widespread,  particularly  in  the  uncleared
areas, where most of the closed schools are located. About 5,600 teaching vacancies exist
in the North East, including in core subjects such as mathematics and science, out of a total
of  28,000  positions.  Teachers  are  unable  to  meet  the  special  needs  of  students  who  have
undergone  severe  trauma  and  disruption  to  their  education.  School  attendance  and
educational attainment among children of displaced families are typically low, and the drop-
out rate is high.

3.

Impacts on Welfare

28.
The majority of displaced people in welfare centers, of which there are about 50 in the
North East, are long-term residents, some of whom have been there for up to 10 years. Most
are  unable  to  return  home  for  security  reasons,  and  have  been  unable  or  are  unwilling  to
relocate elsewhere.

29.
Living  conditions  in  the  welfare  centers  are  generally  extremely  poor  (see  Appendix
2),  with  severe  overcrowding,  lack  of  privacy,  and  inadequate  water  supply  and  sanitation
facilities.  Despite  the  severely  inadequate  living  conditions,  many  families  are  reluctant  to
leave until they can be reassured that the security situation has stabilized and their lives are
no  longer  under  threat.  About  a  third  of  the  families  in  the  welfare  centers  are  especially
vulnerable  and  in  need  of  special  assistance.  In  some  centers  as  many  as  a  quarter  of
families are headed by women. Many children have been orphaned as a result of the conflict,
and are now cared for by relatives or friends. In other families, one or more members have
been  severely  disabled  through  conflict-related  injury.  These  families  are  almost  entirely
dependent  on  Government  and  nongovernment  organization  (NGO)  welfare  programs  and
assistance from relatives.

5. 

Impacts on Agriculture and Irrigation

31.
Paddy cultivation remains the main source of income and employment in the region
although, because of the conflict, the area under paddy has declined from 227,000 hectares
(ha) in 1984 to about 177,000 ha at present. Income levels for families dependent on paddy
production  remain  low,  however,  and  are  significantly  lower  in  uncleared  areas  due  to  the
high  cost  of  inputs  and  lower  paddy  prices.  Vulnerable  groups  and  the  marginalized  poor,
including  landless  families  whose  livelihood  depends  on  casual  seasonal  farm  labor,  have
been especially badly affected. Employment opportunities have been greatly reduced due to
displacement among the farming population and restricted social mobility. This has resulted
in high dependence on relief and remittances from relatives working abroad or in other parts
of  the  country.  Despite  the  reliance  on  paddy  cultivation,  there  is  considerable  scope  for
increasing cultivation of other field crops in higher elevation areas, although there has been
little attempt to do this on a commercial scale to date. This is partly due to the conflict, but
also a reflection of the importance of paddy in the culture of the region.

32.
Irrigation is extensively practiced in the Project area. Several systems date back 1000
years  or  more,  but  most  are  of  more  recent  construction.  In  total  there  are  about  3,000
systems, ranging from small (less than 80 ha—about 2,900 schemes), through medium (80–
600  ha—about  80  schemes),  to  large  (over  600  ha—about  60  schemes).  Many  of  the
schemes  have  ceased  to  function  because  of  direct  conflict-caused  damage,  through
abandonment as populations were displaced, or due to lack of maintenance.

6. 

Impacts on Fisheries

33.
The impact of the conflict on fisheries, and on the communities that depend on fishing
for a living, has been devastating. With the exception of Vavunia, which is entirely landlocked
and  which  offers  considerable  potential  for  inland  fisheries,  the  Project  districts  once
supported thriving coastal fishing communities that before the conflict provided the remainder
of  the  country  with  most  of  its  fish.  For  example,  Jaffna  contributed  26  percent  of  the
country’s total fish production, and almost 60 percent of its dried fish. Overall production of
fresh fish declined from 43,000 tons in 1982 to just 2,300 tons in 1997.

34.
As noted earlier, there are severe restrictions or complete bans on fishing for security
reasons  in  many  areas.  Again  taking  Jaffna  as  an  example,  fishing  was  severely  restricted
for many years, and has been almost totally banned since 1995. In other areas, particularly
on  the  east  coast,  that  were  traditionally  rich  offshore  fishing  grounds,  fishing  is  now
restricted to coastal lagoons or to narrow widths of ocean close to the shore. The result has
been extensive overfishing in the areas that are accessible, and a reduction in the production
of  fish  by  an  average  12  percent  per  year  in  the  1990s.  In  addition,  boats,  equipment,  and
shore-based facilities such as storage sheds, ice plants, and docks have been destroyed by

 9

military  action,  and  institutional  mechanisms and  marketing  channels  that  supported  the
sector have largely collapsed.

7. 

Impacts on Roads

35.
The  Project  area  has  an  extensive  network  of  national  (2,000  kilometer  [km]),
provincial (2,600 km), and rural roads of various types. Other than for some national roads in
the cleared areas, where some maintenance work has been carried out, the network has not
been  improved  or  maintained  since  the  conflict  began.  The  remainder  of  the  network  is
characterized  by  failed  carriageways  and  conflict-caused  damage,  due  either  to  direct
military  action  or  the  passage  of  military  equipment.  Many  of  the  roads  are  no  longer
motorable, and large numbers of bridges and other structures have been destroyed.

36.
 The road network will require extensive rehabilitation before it can effectively support
major reconstruction programs in the Project area (although it is adequate for the relatively
limited activities the Project will undertake), and even more so before it can again provide the
foundation  for  sustained  economic  activity.  However,  it  was  apparent  during  Project
processing,  given  the  strategic  importance  of  roads  military  operations,  that  extensive  road
rehabilitation work would not be possible in the current security climate.

E.

Lessons Learned

ADB  had  earlier  provided  two  loans14  to  assist  the  Government  with  rehabilitating
40.
road  and  education  infrastructure  in  the  North  East.  Although  these  projects  achieved  their
objectives,  their  focus  on  infrastructure  alone  reduces  their  value  as  examples  for  the
proposed  Project,  which  addresses  the  broader  issue  of  assisting  IDPs  with  regaining  a
productive life. However, one lesson that the earlier projects provide, and that is also evident
from  the  ongoing  World  Bank-financed  NEIAP  and  several  bilaterally  financed  projects,  is
that rehabilitation projects should adopt a process approach to permit flexible adjustment of
project  design  during  implementation.  This  will  be  particularly  essential  for  the  proposed
Project,  which  will  be  implemented  in  a  fluid  environment  of  changing  security  conditions,
moving  boundaries  between  cleared  and  uncleared  areas,  and  in  cooperation  with
beneficiaries who are traumatized by many years of flight and the effects of living in insecure
surroundings. The Project will adopt such a process approach (para. 63), with subprojects to
be  selected  during  implementation  against  predefined  criteria,  to  ensure  the  flexibility
required  for  achievement  of  its  objectives.  A  second  lesson  learned,  from  the  education
rehabilitation project, is that rehabilitating infrastructure alone is not sufficient; there must be
teachers  available,  and  also  students,  for  the  completed  facilities  to  achieve  their  purpose.
The proposed Project’s education component will address this by undertaking an analysis of
student  demand  and  teacher availability before an education sector subproject is approved
for implementation.

41.
Other lessons learned from the activities of agencies operating in the Project area are
(i) the need to ensure that, in designing Project components, a balance is maintained among
the  communities—Tamil,  Sinhala,  and  Muslim—that  make  up  the  area’s  population;  (ii)  the
need  to  undertake  activities  in  both  cleared  and  uncleared  areas;  (iii)  the  very  limited
capacity  of  Government  institutions  in  the  Project  area  to  implement  projects;  and  (iv)  the
critical  need  to  coordinate  the  large  number  of  Government  and  externally-assisted
rehabilitation  programs  now  under  implementation  in  the  Project  area,  a  situation  that  will
become more acute when the conflict ends.

IV.

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A.

Rationale

48.
The armed conflict between the Sri Lankan Government and the LTTE commenced in
1983,  although  its  causes  date  from  a  much  earlier  period.  The  disruption  of  economic
activity  is  estimated  to  have  decreased  the  contribution  of  the  Northern  and  Eastern
provinces to national GDP from 15 percent in the 1980s to 4 percent in 1997. Between 70 to
90  percent  of  the  population  in  the  North  East  is  estimated  to  be  below  the  poverty  level,
compared with around 25 percent on average in the remainder of the country. The scale of
the  destruction  and  dislocation  has  so  strained  the  Government’s  ability  to  provide
assistance that it has decided to request the international community, including ADB as one
of  the  Government’s  leading  development  partners,  for  support.  The  proposed  Project  will
provide  a  portion  of  that  support  within  a  relatively  short  time  frame,  through  its  use  of  the
disaster rehabilitation modality.

B.

Objectives

49.
The  objective  of  the  proposed  Project,  as  described  in  the  Project  Framework
(Appendix 1), is to contribute to the Government’s overall relief and rehabilitation program for
the  North  East,  by  improving  the  living  conditions  and  well-being  of  communities  that  have
been  affected  by  the  conflict,  particularly  those  that  contain  significant  proportions  of  IDPs.
The Project will be part of the Government’s overall relief and rehabilitation program for the
North  East  as  previously  described,  and  will  coordinate  closely  with  projects  and  programs
financed by the Government and other international and domestic agencies.

C.

Scope

51.
The  Project  will  implement  a  range  of  complementary  activities,  to  ensure  that  the
people  living  in  the  Project  area,  whether  original  occupants  or  people  who  have  been
resettled  or  relocated,  experience  a  broad  improvement  in  their  livelihoods,  and  in  their
access to services, utilities, and income-generating opportunities. The Project will have two
broad  components:  larger  scale  anchor  subprojects  and  smaller  scale  community-level
subprojects.  The  former,  which  will  typically  consist  of  investments  that  will  benefit  a  broad
cross-section of each district’s population, will be implemented largely through conventional
Government contracting arrangements. The latter, which will typically consist of investments
for  individuals  or  specific  communities,  will  be  implemented  by  local  organizations  and
communities as implementing partners assisted by service providers (Government agencies
at the province, district, and division level; project field staff; and NGOs).

limited  extent;  and,  across  sectors,  income  generation.  The  activity  list  is  not  exhaustive

V.

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A.

Impact on Poverty and Other benefits

88.
The  population  of  the  North  East  experiences  poverty  levels  that  are  much  higher
than  elsewhere  in  the  country.  Estimates  of  poverty  range  from  60  to  90  percent,  although
there have been few detailed studies to confirm this. It is apparent from information available
with the Government’s rehabilitation agencies and the district level Government Agents that
IDPs in particular suffer acutely from lack of access to food, security, Government services,
and  the  means  to  earn  their  own  livings.  This  situation  is  much  more  pronounced  in
uncleared areas. The proposed Project will begin to address the needs of the IDPs, and also
of the existing populations among whom the IDPs have been settled. The overall impact will
be some reduction in the level of poverty of a substantial proportion of the population in the
Project area, and an improvement in the general standard of living of those whom the Project
directly affects. In particular, the health component should reduce the presently high levels of
sickness and disease, and the education component should begin to address the impacts of
inadequate schooling on children in the area. No attempt has been made to quantify these
impacts,  since  baseline  data  are  not  available.  However,  the  detailed  monitoring  and
evaluation  program  that  the  Project  will  develop  and  implement  will  provide  a  progressive
indication  of  the  Project’s  impacts  over  its  implementation  period.  Finally,  the  requirement
that a significant portion of the Project be implemented by the beneficiaries themselves will
begin  a  process  of  regaining  self-reliance,  creating  incomes,  and  developing  marketable
skills.

THE EXPERIENCE OF DISPLACEMENT1

A.

Introduction

The decision to flee from home is not one taken lightly, and it requires the threat of death or
1.
injury to compel people to  leave  home and seek refuge elsewhere. The flight to safety is fraught
with  danger,  and  people  continue  to  be  threatened  by  shelling,  snipers  and  landmines.  As  a
precondition  of  permission  to  leave  Liberation  Tiger  of  Tamil  Eelam  (LTTE)-controlled  areas  for
Government  controlled  areas,  people  are  often  required  to  pay  substantial  amounts  of  money
and/or to hand over property to the militant force. People then travel long distances on foot or by
vehicle for many days with limited quantities of food and water. They usually spend nights at some
temporary shelter among chaotic social and environmental conditions. Almost half of all internally
displaced  people  (IDPs)  are  children,  some  of  whom  experience  separation  from  families,
exploitation, abuse, and/or abduction into militant groups.

2.
Though the main aim of flight is to obtain safe refuge, people find that the allotted spaces in
welfare  centers  are  hardly  conducive  to  protection  and  peace  of  mind.  Because  of  the  nature  of
continued  armed  conflict,  IDPs  are  often  located  within  or  close  to  advancing  lines  of  armed
activity, and as a result experience repeated displacements. It should also be noted that there are
large numbers of displaced persons in LTTE-controlled areas who do not reside in welfare centers
and  who  continue  to  live  in  jungle  areas  without  any  shelter,  food,  water,  or  sanitation  facilities.
Exact or even approximate figures of this population are not known. Restrictions on food shipments
into these areas are related to the census of 1981, the last census taken, and it is likely that these
people suffer severe food shortages.

3.
To flee from one's home is to experience a deep sense of loss. People leave behind assets,
property,  relatives,  friends,  familiar  surroundings,  and  established  social  networks.  Reasons  put
forth  by  persons  include  threat  from  militants  due  to  associations  with  paramilitary  and  political
groups,  loss  of  livelihood  and  employment  opportunities,  and  armed  conflict  situations  that  put
people in immediate danger of death. Most of the problems experienced by IDPs are related to the
prevailing  security  situation,  education,  employment,  recreation,  violations  of  human  rights,  and
restrictions on mobility.

B.

Security and Protection

4.
Following  either  forced  or  voluntary  displacement,  IDPs  eventually  find  themselves  in  a
temporary transit camp where the details of the flight, route taken, and reasons for departure are
investigated.  After  this  procedure,  they  are  then  assigned  to  welfare  centers,  where  further
intensive investigations are conducted for a period of 2–3 months, during which their movements
are restricted.

5.
During  this  process,  unbeknown  to  most  IDPs,  they  enter  into  an  unwritten  pact  in  which
they are obliged to renounce their freedoms, especially that of movement, in exchange for aid and
protection.  A  defining  feature  of  welfare  centers  is  the  societal,  legal,  and  administrative
“separateness”  of  the  camp  from  the  surroundings  such  that  the  laws  and  regulations  of  the
country often cease to exist. Welfare centers are often highly militarized, and people have to obtain
permission to engage in common daily functions such as attending school, finding employment, or

6.
To access activities external to the welfare centers, documentation and security clearances
are dispensed by officials of the center, who thus wield great power over the lives of people under
their charge. People stand in queues every day in order to obtain a 24-hour pass that allows them
to go out in search of work or even in some cases to go to school. People are expected to be back
in the camp by 6:00 p.m. In addition, the distribution of resources such as food, water, firewood,
and  plastic  sheeting  is  often  controlled  by  male  officials,  which  negatively  affects  access  to
resources for women and female heads of households.

C.

Shelter

7.
Shelters  in  welfare  centers  often  take  the  form  of  large  halls  from  converted  schools  or
other  community  buildings.  Rooms  within  these  halls  are  created  by  partitioning  with  plastic
sheeting, wood, or bamboo sheets. Extensions to the initial setup are made by constructing huts
around the main building. The room or hut is the living, sleeping, cooking, and changing space for
all  members  in  a  family,  which  often  does  not  afford  a  sense  of  privacy  even  from  other  families
because of poor construction.

The huts allow little protection against flood and rain, and following a heavy rain, people are
8.
forced to share huts with others who have not been flooded or whose roofs are not yet leaking. The
maintenance of the fragile construction is difficult, and consequently deterioration is rapid.

D.

Food

9.
The  main  source  of  food  is  dry  rations  distributed  by  government  and  humanitarian
agencies.  However,  this  is  often  not  enough  and  has  to  be  supplemented  by  labor,  home
gardening, and/or other income-generating activities. People often cope by eating only one or two
meals per day, and food insecurity is high.

10.
One of the major concerns expressed by recipients of relief aid is that distribution needs to
be conducted in a fair and transparent manner. People are often not given information about what
they  will  be  receiving  and  about  their  entitlements.  Thus,  people  waste  resources  on  things  they
would  receive  later.  The  irregular  and  somewhat  erratic  supply  of  dry  rations  mean  that  at  times
families do not get rations for two months and at times might receive two months' supply at once.

11.
Although  dry  rations  are  a  major  coping  mechanism,  people  perceive  long-term  relief  as
more  important,  and  have  often  voiced  the  desire  to  be  assisted  in  regaining  the  ability  to  earn
money and food.

E.

Water and sanitation

12.
There  is  a  severe  need  for  proper  water  and  sanitation  facilities.  Access  to  drinking  and
bathing water is limited, which impacts severely on lifestyle through having to walk long distances
to  obtain  water.  Usually  the  burden  of  getting  water  falls  on  women,  so  that  women's  abilities  to
engage in income-generating activities are hampered. Additionally, there are long waits for bathing
and  toilet  facilities;  people  often  wake  up  as  early  as  3:00  a.m.  to  use  the  facilities.  Safety  and
security  concerns  for  women  in  camps  include  being  subjected  to  harassment  if  facilities  are
located publicly, and they are vulnerable to assault if facilities are located in isolated positions.

common  or  private  wells.  As  a  result,  people  often  use  irrigation  reservoir  water  for  drinking
purposes,  and  sometimes  even  for  bathing,  giving  rise  to  skin  infections  and  other  diseases.  In
some  occasions,  people  have  dug  their  own  ground  wells.  However  without  proper  cement
casings, these wells are not durable sources of water.

F.

Employment

The  highest  priority  of  people  in  welfare  centers  is  becoming  self-sufficient  and  gaining  a
14.
measure  of  self-reliance  through  access  to  regular  income  and  employment.  Employment  was
stated  as  the  most  important  concern  in  welfare  centers,  with  food,  education,  and  employment
being  perceived  as  closely  linked.  In  a  study  conducted  by  Oxfam  and  Save  the  Children  Fund
(1999)  among  IDPs,  people  have  ranked  their  own  concerns  in  the  order  of  employment,  water,
education, food, health, shelter, nonfood-related items, and clothing. As preconditions for returning
to their former homes, people ranked security, shelter, employment, latrines, water, and education
as the most important factors.

15.
The displaced population in camps consists mainly of landless farming families and those
who  engage  in  casual  labor.  People  from  other  social  backgrounds  have  often  resources  in  the
form of friends or finance that they utilize to move out from centers as soon as possible.

16.
The remaining population encounters a number of obstacles in the attempt to gain access
to  employment.  Daily  passes  need  to  be  obtained  in  order  to  work  outside  the  camp,  and  these
may be withdrawn if security risks are perceived by security guards. Usually, passes are easier to
obtain  for  those  people  who  have  higher  social  status  or  who  use  wealth  or  valuable  assets  to
obtain preferential treatment. People with lower social status or who are in fact poorer find it more
difficult to obtain the passes. It is especially difficult for female-headed households to gain access
to  resources  that  create  conditions  for  employment  opportunities.  The  imposition  of  curfew  times
on welfare center residents also poses restraints on the amount and type of work possible. Threats
to  physical  safety  also  restrict  people's  mobility.  The  threat  of  landmines,  forcible  recruitment,
and/or security restrictions on access to land limit people to using paths that are well-known to be
free of landmines.

17.
In  such  circumstances,  the  search  for  temporary  employment  is  often  assisted  by  the
natural diversity of skills and the ability to learn new skills within the population. People engage in
casual employment or self-employment such as agricultural labor, construction of roads, collecting
firewood,  making  coir  ropes,  preparing  charcoal,  weaving  palm  leaf  mats,  weaving  palm  roofing,
pottery, brickmaking, bicycle repair, poultry, masonry, carpentry, toddy tapping, and various small
scale income-generating activities.

However, the nature of these activities is marked by irregularities in income, the paucity of
18.
resources, the scarcity of markets and spending power, and restrictions of material inputs. Welfare
centers located close to towns usually fare much better than those located in more remote areas in
terms  of  employment  opportunities.  People  stated  that  items  required  for  generating  self-
employment and income are seeds, agricultural implements, fishing tackle, fuel, skills training and
access  to  markets.  People  mentioned  that  being  able  to  obtain  loans  and  setting  up  revolving
funds were helpful activities.

Understanding  of  the  social  complexities  of  each  welfare  center  is  needed  in  order  to  plan
appropriate interventions that account for and respect difference. Providers of assistance, whether
Government of NGO, are attempting to create new communities that consist of disparate classes
and castes, the latter being a particularly sensitive issue for Tamil communities who make up the
largest proportion of IDPs in the Project area. The shared space of displacement is often all that
the welfare center residents share. Prior to displacement they would have led separate lives within
accepted  social  parameters  and  norms  of  their  social  groupings  and  differences.  Sleeping  under
the same roof, working in the same fields, and drinking from and bathing at the same well would
have  been  unthinkable  and  intolerable.  In  the  welfare  centers,  however,  this  is  the  situation  that
the  welfare  center  community  becomes  perceived  by  outsiders  as  being
prevails,  and 
homogenous.

20.
This  assumption  distort  the  consultation  process  that  is  the  foundation  of  an  effective
rehabilitation  program.  Spokespersons  for  the  community  emerge  from  the  upper  echelons  of
predisplaced social hierarchy. The social deference and respect afforded to these people lead to
acceptance  that  they  are  good  representatives  for  the  needs  of  these  communities.  However,
resentment may well fester over the pecking order of access to resources over time and result in
sabotage of community initiatives.

21.
The  fragmentation  of  village  structure  and  hierarchy  and  the  lack  of  traditional  forms  of
authority and social organization that before their displacement helped people negotiate problems
largely  render  invalid  any  community  initiatives.  The  role  and  place  of  village  elder,  rural  priest,
landowner,  petty  trader,  agricultural  laborer  is  quite  well  defined  in  the  pre-displaced  structure.
However, in the new mosaic, social positioning ceases to exist, with social fluidity undermining the
possibility  of  community  organization.  The  desegregation  of  needs  is  often  gender-based  and
overlooks the issues of caste and class.

22.
Displaced  populations  are  complex  societies.  When  traditional  systems  of  protection  are
strained or broken down completely, there are often high levels of violence, alcohol and substance
abuse, family quarrels, and sexual assault. The welfare centers exhibit all of these characteristics
to varying degrees.

H.

Education

23.
IDPs  in  welfare  centers  emphasize  schooling  and  education  for  their  children.  The  most
common  form  of  education  there  is  non-formal.  Temporary  schools  or  extensions  of  host
community schools allow children access to formal schooling, although a number of factors hinder
its continuity.

24.
Being temporary, the schools are often poorly constructed, and lack adequate numbers of
teachers. Overcrowding and high student-teacher ratios adversely affect the quality of education.
Additionally, the ability to obtain the necessities such as educational materials and clothing affects
children's  attitudes  towards  school,  with  many  leaving  to  supplement  household  income  through
additional work. Parents often sell dry rations and other valuables for the purpose of obtaining the
necessary  materials  for  education  and  supporting  local  teachers.  Children  for  their  part  forego
meals in order to buy books. Often the curriculum is not completed, because of the inadequacy of
the number of teachers and the difficulty in conducting regular classes.

In  instances  where  children  do  not  possess  the  required  documents  such  as  birth

I.

Health

26.
In  welfare  centers  there  is  high  mortality  of  children,  as  measles,  diarrheal  diseases,
malaria,  and  malnutrition  become  rife  and  are  hard  to  control.  Contributing  factors  are
overcrowding, lack of food and clean water, poor sanitation, and lack of shelter. With deterioration
in  public  health  services,  practices,  and  awareness,  and  with  reduced  access  to  reproductive
health services and family planning, people are unable to exert much control over their own state
of  health  and  well-being.  These  factors  are  compounded  by  the  lack  of  medical  supplies,  poor
access to hospitals and health centers, and the presence of infectious or contagious diseases with
no proper facilities for quarantine.

27.
In  addition  to  exposure  to  conditions  that  are  conducive  to  ill  health  and  disease,  social
problems  create  vulnerability  to  disease.  The  risk  of  suicide  for  both  men  and  women  is    high  in
situations of displacement and residence in welfare centers due to feelings of frustration caused by
lack of mobility, the lack of upward opportunities, and a sense of helplessness and hopelessness.

quickly.

(vi)  Maintain  contact  with  the  UNHCR  for  works  being  undertaken  in  uncleared  areas

and, whenever possible, visit subproject sites in those areas.

C. 

Consultants for Anchor Project Design and Construction

10.
The  Project  will  implement  a  substantial  number  of  subprojects,  referred  to  as  anchor
subprojects,  that  will  require  designing,  or  reviewing  designs,  and  supervising  construction  of
various buildings and civil works. Since the detailed scope of each of these subprojects will not be
finalized  until  the  Project  has  commenced,  consultants  will  be  selected  on  the  basis  of
requirements at the time. The selection will be made from panels of suitably qualified consultants,
to be provided by domestic consulting firms. The broad scope of work for the consultants will be as
follows:

(i) 

Prepare designs and contract documentation for anchor subprojects, using standard
designs and documents where possible but for health sector projects, base designs
on the report of the international health specialist.

(ii) 

Assist the PD with procuring contractors for the subprojects.

(iii) 

(iv) 

Supervise  construction  of  the  subprojects,  including  measuring  work  done  for
payment  purposes,  monitoring  quality  in  accordance  with  specifications,  and
certifying payments.

Ensure that all contract conditions are understood and enforced, including approvals
of  materials  and  work  methods,  penalties  for  late  completion,  removal  of
nonconforming work, correction of defects, etc.

(v) 

(vi) 

(vii) 

Report to the PD on the status of all contracts under implementation at the end of
each month, using a standard format to be developed and agreed upon during the
Project’s inception period.

Prepare  specifications  and  contract  documentation  for  equipment  subprojects,  for
health, education, water supply and sanitation, and other sectors where required.

Assist  the  PD  with  procuring  the  equipment,  including  inspecting  quality,  certifying
payment, and ensuring that contract provisions are observed.

11.
The  presently  estimated  consultant  requirement,  all  domestic,  for  design  and  construction
supervision  services  is  about  700  person-months,  primarily  for  design  and  site  supervision  staff.
This  estimate  is  based  on  the  design  and  documentation  activities  being  completed  within  two
years (200 person-months), and the supervision activities extending over five years with four full-
time  field  consultants,  each  covering  two  districts  (300  person-months)  plus  management,
technical  and  administration  support.  Support  equipment  and  facilities,  such  as  vehicles,
computers, etc, will be included in the scope of the consulting services contract, and will be funded
through the Project loan.

D. 

Consultants for Community Mobilization and Participation

12.
Since the Project includes a substantial proportion of activities that are to be implemented
at  the  community  level,  there  will  be  a  requirement  for  support  to  assist  communities,  and  the
Government agencies that work with them, with effectively managing the community mobilization
and participation process. A small portion of the required staffing will be provided through the GTZ
Management Team (see Appendix 8), but the balance will be provided through the Project.

13.
The detailed scope of work for the social mobilization consultants will be developed during
the Project’s inception period. Inputs required will be about 1,440 person-months, based on three
consultants (young graduates) for each of the eight districts, for the duration of the Project.
